In the olden days, people wouldn't die of cancer or heart disease like we do today, mostly because they didn't live long enough to develop those diseases. They would die by being crushed in industrial accidents in one of the few factories around at that time, or mauled to death by an ox or from injury or infection. Since the development of antibiotics in 1928, people have lived a lot longer becuase we could treat those infections with this new regimen. 12-15% of allied soldiers were estimated to be saved from infection using antibiotics. The leading cause of death throughout history has primarily been due to injuries and infection. While this went away after antibiotics were invented, deaths from infection are on the rise because bacteria continue to evolve to combat the vaccines we develop. Now bacteria evolve so quickly that it isn't financially worth it to companies to keep developing new strains of antibiotics.

Historically, humans did not live long enough to die from things like cancer, heart failure, etc. Many people died after receiving injuries - whether animal wounds from hunting, or being crushed by rocks, or war wounds, or factory accidents - and the infections that followed those injuries.
But after penicillin was discovered in the early 20th century by Mr. Fleming, infections became possible to treat. Infections that once killed people, could now be cured within days, and easily. This resulted in a dramatic number of lives saved during World War I; somewhere between 10-15% of Allied forces by some estimates. Death from infections dropped dramatically everywhere.
But this is now changing. Bacteria evolve and develop resistances to antibiotic drugs, and for decades companies were constantly developing new drugs to kill bacteria as they became resistant to old ones. And now there are "superbugs" - types of bacteria that are immune to most, if not all, available antibiotics. And pharmaceutical companies are finding it too hard to develop new drugs. Already some 700,000 peopel a year are dying by infections worldwide, and if a solution isn't found by 2050 that number could rise to 10,000,000 a year - about the population of NYC.
There may come a day when only one or two, or no drugs at work on a given infection. And one way to combat this is by reducing our antibiotic use. Don't prescribe antibiotics to common childhood illnesses like earaches if we are not certain it is the right drug, don't buy or eat foods raised with animal treated with antibiotics, and other similar actions.

Back then, people didn't die from cancer or heart disease, they didn't live long enough to experience these problems as they were killed by animals, died in the war, or were killed in factory jobs. When antibiotics came into the picture, this led to saving millions of lives, especially for the allied forces in WWII. This penicillin is even used today. But now people have begun to die again because of resistance to antibiotics. This includes MRSA and many other strains of bacterium. The weaker organism dies off, but the survivors come back even stronger than before leading to a back and forth between the two until we reach our inevitable outcome in a post-antibiotic world. Even pharmaceuticals companies want no stake in this losing war.

The discovery of penicillin by Alexander Flemming changed the world and the way we treat infections. Penicillin is still used today as an antibiotic and prompted the development of hundreds more. Flemming's discovery aided in World War II, reducing Allied deaths by 10-15%. Antibiotics have also allowed people to live far longer than in the past. People used to die from injury, or infection, but due to this prolonged longevity, we are now dying from lifestyle diseases like heart disease.

The current number of worldwide deaths due to infection is around 700,000 and is actually anticipated to only rise. By 2050, the estimated toll will be around 10 million. Why? Antibiotic resistance or the rise in "superbugs" renders current antibiotics useless and allows bacteria to thrive. The use of antibiotics is like a game of leapfrog; as we develop new antibiotics, the bacteria become resistant, so we develop new drugs, and so on. These bacteria will only continue to develop resistance against antibiotics if we continue to overuse antibiotics. We need to cut back on our use of antibiotics for every little ailment, or soon this problem will be out of control.

Throughout most of human history, people did not typically die from heart disease or cancers. The died young from gun shot wounds, factory accidents, falling off a horse, or (most of the time) from infections, as a result of those injuries. 

Death by infection forever changed in the 1920's when antibiotics were discovered. Millions of lives have been saved in the decades since and people are living longer lives. But antibiotic resistance is gaining considerable ground and we are becoming more at risk of death by bacteria. "Superbugs" have been getting worse and killing many people. The problem is expected to worsen. Currently in the U.S. and Europe, about 50,000 people die a year from infections that cannot be treated. That number is expected to rise to 10 million a year by 2050, unless we can do something to stop it.

Tiny steps can be taken now to help stave off disaster later, like not taking unnecessary antibiotics or not consuming meats raised on antibiotics.

Throughout history, mankind has been susceptible to injury and death by misadventure, occupational hazards, and a host of infections and diseases. Many people never reached old age due to death from common sicknesses. Once Fleming's invention of antibiotics were introduced, illnesses and injuries that would have killed before were now able to be treated. However, as time has progressed, our bodies have adapted and so have the diseases. We are starting to see extensive evidence of drug-resistant bugs, which could be the result of overuse of antibiotics. If something does not change in the way we prescribe and use these drugs, it is estimated that by the year 2050, as many as 10 million people a year could die to drug-resistant illnesses. That's the equivalent of the population of New York City.
